Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `‚Ñù‚â•0‚àû`.

type: {Œ± : Type u_1} ‚Üí {_m : MeasurableSpace Œ±} ‚Üí MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc Œ± ENNReal ‚Üí MeasureTheory.Measure Œ± ‚Üí ENNReal
name: MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.lintegral
docString: Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `‚Ñù‚â•0‚àû`.

If for a measurable function $f$ and a sequence of sets $a\_i$ with finite measures, the average of $|f(y) - c|$ over $a\_i$ converges to $0$, and for each $g\_i$ supported in $a\_i$ with integral $1$ and supremum bounded by $K/\mu(a\_i)$, then $\lim \int g\_i(y) f(y) d\mu = c$.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E]
  [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} {Œπ : Type u_4} {a : Œπ ‚Üí Set Œ±} {l : Filter Œπ} {f : Œ± ‚Üí E}
  {c : E} {g : Œπ ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (K : ‚Ñù),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚®ç (y : Œ±) in a i, ‚Äñf y - c‚Äñ ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds 0) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f (a i) Œº) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚à´ (y : Œ±), g i y ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds 1) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, Function.support (g i) ‚äÜ a i) ‚Üí
          (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, ‚àÄ (x : Œ±), |g i x| ‚â§ K / (‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (a i)).toReal) ‚Üí
            Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚à´ (y : Œ±), g i y ‚Ä¢ f y ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds c)
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_integral_smul_of_tendsto_average_norm_sub
docString: If for a measurable function $f$ and a sequence of sets $a\_i$ with finite measures, the average of $|f(y) - c|$ over $a\_i$ converges to $0$, and for each $g\_i$ supported in $a\_i$ with integral $1$ and supremum bounded by $K/\mu(a\_i)$, then $\lim \int g\_i(y) f(y) d\mu = c$.

This is a statement of Cauchy's Mean Value Theorem in the context of real-valued functions. It states that given two functions `f` and `g` which are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` and differentiable on the open interval `(a, b)`, there exists a point `c` in the open interval `(a, b)` such that the ratio of the differences of `f` and `g` at the endpoints of the interval, i.e. `(g b - g a) / (f b - f a)`, equals the ratio of their derivatives at the point `c`, that is `(g' c) / (f' c)`. Here, `f'` and `g'` denote the derivatives of `f` and `g` respectively. The theorem essentially states that at some point in `(a, b)`, the rates of change of the two functions are proportional to the overall rate of change over the interval.

type:
‚àÄ (f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) ‚Üí
        ‚àÄ (g g' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
          ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
            (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt g (g' x) x) ‚Üí ‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, (g b - g a) * f' c = (f b - f a) * g' c
name: exists_ratio_hasDerivAt_eq_ratio_slope
docString: This is a statement of Cauchy's Mean Value Theorem in the context of real-valued functions. It states that given two functions `f` and `g` which are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` and differentiable on the open interval `(a, b)`, there exists a point `c` in the open interval `(a, b)` such that the ratio of the differences of `f` and `g` at the endpoints of the interval, i.e. `(g b - g a) / (f b - f a)`, equals the ratio of their derivatives at the point `c`, that is `(g' c) / (f' c)`. Here, `f'` and `g'` denote the derivatives of `f` and `g` respectively. The theorem essentially states that at some point in `(a, b)`, the rates of change of the two functions are proportional to the overall rate of change over the interval.

If the average of a function `f` along a sequence of sets `a‚Çô` converges to `c` (more precisely,
we require that `‚®ç y in a i, ‚Äñf y - c‚Äñ ‚àÇŒº` tends to `0`), then the integral of `g‚Çô ‚Ä¢ f` also tends
to `c` if `g‚Çô` is supported in `a‚Çô`, has integral converging to one and supremum at most `K / Œº a‚Çô`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E]
  [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} {Œπ : Type u_4} {a : Œπ ‚Üí Set Œ±} {l : Filter Œπ} {f : Œ± ‚Üí E}
  {c : E} {g : Œπ ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (K : ‚Ñù),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚®ç (y : Œ±) in a i, ‚Äñf y - c‚Äñ ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds 0) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f (a i)) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚à´ (y : Œ±), g i y ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds 1) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, Function.support (g i) ‚äÜ a i) ‚Üí
          (‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œπ) in l, ‚àÄ (x : Œ±), |g i x| ‚â§ K / ENNReal.toReal (‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (a i))) ‚Üí
            Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ‚à´ (y : Œ±), g i y ‚Ä¢ f y ‚àÇŒº) l (nhds c)
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_integral_smul_of_tendsto_average_norm_sub
docString:
If the average of a function `f` along a sequence of sets `a‚Çô` converges to `c` (more precisely,
we require that `‚®ç y in a i, ‚Äñf y - c‚Äñ ‚àÇŒº` tends to `0`), then the integral of `g‚Çô ‚Ä¢ f` also tends
to `c` if `g‚Çô` is supported in `a‚Çô`, has integral converging to one and supremum at most `K / Œº a‚Çô`.

For any nonempty measurable space Œ© with finite, non-zero measure Œº, and any function f from Œ© to a normed add-commutative group E over the real numbers, the average of f is equal to the integral of its normalized version with respect to Œº.

name: MeasureTheory.FiniteMeasure.average_eq_integral_normalize
docString: For any nonempty measurable space Œ© with finite, non-zero measure Œº, and any function f from Œ© to a normed add-commutative group E over the real numbers, the average of f is equal to the integral of its normalized version with respect to Œº.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is periodic with a positive period `c`, then for every value `x` we can find a `y` in the left-closed right-open interval from 0 to `c` (denoted `Ico 0 c`), such that `f(x) = f(y)`. In other words, within every period of the function, you can find a value that the function has already taken in the first instance of that period.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} {c : Œ±} [inst : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup Œ±] [inst_1 : Archimedean Œ±],
  Function.Periodic f c ‚Üí 0 < c ‚Üí ‚àÄ (x : Œ±), ‚àÉ y ‚àà Set.Ico 0 c, f x = f y
name: Function.Periodic.exists_mem_Ico‚ÇÄ
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is periodic with a positive period `c`, then for every value `x` we can find a `y` in the left-closed right-open interval from 0 to `c` (denoted `Ico 0 c`), such that `f(x) = f(y)`. In other words, within every period of the function, you can find a value that the function has already taken in the first instance of that period.

If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X ‚Üí Y} {a b : X} {l : Y},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Ioo a b) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a (Set.Ioi a)) (nhds l) ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b (Set.Iio b)) (nhds l) ‚Üí ‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, IsExtrOn f (Set.Ioo a b) c
name: exists_isExtrOn_Ioo_of_tendsto
docString:
If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
has a local extremum at some point of the corresponding open interval.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X ‚Üí Y} {a b : X},
  a < b ‚Üí ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí f a = f b ‚Üí ‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, IsLocalExtr f c

docString:
A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
has a local extremum at some point of the corresponding open interval.

A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
takes either its maximum or its minimum value at a point in the interior of the interval.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]

  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X ‚Üí Y} {a b : X},

name: exists_Ioo_extr_on_Icc
docString:
A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `a` from the right or from the left,
then `u ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x in u..b, f x` has right (resp., left) derivative `-c` at `a`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {c : E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {s t : Set ‚Ñù} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter a (nhdsWithin a s) (nhdsWithin a t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin a t) ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a t ‚äì MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) ‚Üí
          HasDerivWithinAt (fun u => ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in u..b, f x) (-c) s a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_hasDerivWithinAt_of_tendsto_ae_left
docString:

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {c : E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {s t : Set ‚Ñù} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter b (nhdsWithin b s) (nhdsWithin b t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin b t) ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b t ‚äì MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) ‚Üí
          autoParam (UniqueDiffWithinAt ‚Ñù s b) _auto‚úù ‚Üí derivWithin (fun u => ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..u, f x) s b = c

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E},
